title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: Funds will support veterinary operations to deploy security tracking equipment on Zambias reintroduced population of southern black rhinos and advanced training for anti-poaching staff. Specific activities will 1) include expenses to bring in veterinarians and pilots for a seven day immobilization operation to dart clean (unmarked) rhinos and install VHF transmitters in 5 rhinos and Argos satellite transmitters on two rhinos; 2) ongoing monitoring of rhinos for anti-poaching purposes including operating costs for ground patrols, outposts and 100 hours of aerial surveillance flights; and 3) employing a trainer for advanced training for 15 ZAWA patrol leaders.

title.narrative: African Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "This project will increase the effectiveness of law enforcement operations in Nsumbu National Park on Lake Tanganyika, Zambia; as well as providing requirements to ensure an increased presence of wildlife police officers in the NE sector of Nsumbu National Park to secure the highly vulnerable African elephant population there. Due to the nature of Nsumbu National Park lake patrols and deployments by boat are essential in LE activities..Specific activities will include equipping the ZAWA patrol boat with all necessary equipment for operating along the shores of Nsumbu NP including night patrols and providing mobile support for terrestrial based operations..The provision of increased amounts of petrol and field rations will increase the utilisation of available manpower to Nsumbu Management Unit for law enforcement operations resulting in a higher number of patrol days per month and reduced poaching incidents."

title.narrative: Black rhino population monitoring and protection management operations in North Luangwa National Park, Zambia

description.narrative: This grant will fortify protection of the North Luangwa ecosystem for the protection of Zambia's only black rhino population. Funds will support specialized training courses on site for senior and junior rangers from the national wildlife authority and from local communities, refurbishment and running costs of an airplane for surveillance and security patrols, annual veterinary operations to deploy security tracking equipment on individual rhinos, and operating costs for rhino monitoring and for anti-poaching ground patrols.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: Funds will support rhino-focused environmental education programs in and around North Luangwa National Park in Zambia. Specific activities will include visits by the Lolesha Luangwa education team to local schools and communities, support for designated Conservation Teachers at each school, trips on the custom-built and specially equipped education bus by students and community members into North Luangwa National Park. Ongoing training and mentorship of the local education officers and an exchange visit to the rhino education program in Tanzania are also supported.

title.narrative: Wildife Without Borders-Critically Endangered Animals

description.narrative: This project will conserve the Luangwa Valley population of African wild dogs through increasing and improving anti-snaring patrols by community village scouts in game management areas and to address the veterinary need to rescue snared and injured wild dogs. Specific objectives include: (1) Supporting community based and ZAWA wildlife police officer anti-poaching patrols; (2) Supporting aerial based monitoring and coordination of ground patrols, aerial surveillance of wild dog populations and their habitat and monitoring of poaching; (3) Supporting the SLCS/ZCP wildlife veterinary program; (4) Providing ten scouts with the necessary and modern equipment to perform effective patrols from Kanzutu wildlife camp; (5) Conducting community anti-snaring sensitization campaigns in Malama Chiefdom.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: African Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in Luangwa Valley, Zambia, by maintaining anti-poaching patrols and by developing a detection dog unit to reduce illegal killing of elephants and to disrupt the illegal trade in wildlife. Specific activities include: (1) rations for ground patrols to support law enforcement in the South Luangwa National Park and the Lupande Game Management Area; (2) support for game scouts at remote fly camps in the park to provide anti-poaching surveillance in areas targeted by poachers; and (3) development of a detection dog unit to be deployed at roadblocks, borders, the airport, and other wildlife contraband hotspots. Handlers and dogs will be trained to detect ivory, bushmeat, rhino horn, and animal skins.

To increase support for black rhino conservation and the protected areas, this grant supports the production of lesson plans and resource materials for 21 local schools, school visits by the NLCP outreach officer, training and mentoring for the officer and for appointed conservation teachers at each school, Conservation Celebration Days held; and field trips by school or community groups into North Luangwa National Park.

title.narrative: Protecting Endangered Vultures and other Threatened Wildlife of the Kasanka..National Park, Zambia

description.narrative: this project will strengthen conservation measures around the core vulture breeding and roosting area in Kasanka National Park. Specific objectives include: (1) Strengthening of law-enforcement operations; (2) Ensuring total exclusion of fires from the sensitive evergreen forests in which vultures breed and roost; (3) improving accessibility to the core area to enable law-enforcement, fire fighting, tourism operations and other protection measures (4) Generating additional funds through tourism in order to improve financial sustainability for protection activities while reducing disturbance for breeding

title.narrative: Proposal for a wildlife crime detection dog unit, Lusaka

description.narrative: Funds will support the establishment of a Wildlife Crime Detection Dog Unit based in Lusaka, Zambia. The unit will consist of four detection dogs trained to identify ivory, firearms and other wildlife products and six dog handlers to be deployed at key border posts and airports, public transport centers, and roadblocks. Specific activities will include procuring four pre-screened dogs, transport of the dogs to Zambia, handler selection and trainer of handlers, equipment, and procurement of supplies for dog maintenance, veterinary care and training.

Specific activities will include providing rations, equipment and deployment needs to the canine and investigations units, supporting aerial surveillance over the national park and game management areas and providing technical support through the SLCS operations manager.

description.narrative: In adherence with the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) Resolution 10.10, all countries are expected to report a national inventory of ivory stockpiles. This grant will support independent experts to plan and conduct an inventory of Zambias ivory and to create a long-term data management system. All activities will be conducted with appropriate Zambia government officials, who will be trained to carry on annual inventories and upkeep the database in future.

title.narrative: Combatting the Emerging Trade in Big Cats and Pangolins in the Luangwa Valley, Zambia

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to improve leopard, lion, and pangolin conservation in Zambia and reduce poaching mortalities of these species. Wildlife anti-trafficking efforts have focused on elephants and rhinos in Africa; however there is increasing evidence that trade in other threatened species is rapidly increasing, making collaboration with existing anti-trafficking efforts of paramount importance. In collaboration.with Investigations and Intelligence Units under the Department of National Parks and Wildlife, Conservation South Luangwa has already identified the border city of Chipata to be a major hub of wildlife trafficking and collectively the collaborating partners are well-placed to expand anti-trafficking efforts to combat these new threats. Specific activities will include: (1) working with wildlife investigators to identify and understand the origins of the trade; (2) identifying key perpetrators involved in trafficking; and (3) ensuring perpetrators are arrested and convicted. title.narrative: Restructuring law enforcement in Kasanka National Park to safeguard the last viable elephant.population in the Greater Bangweulu Wetland Area, Zambia

description.narrative: Kasanka National Park in northern Zambia is home to the last viable population of African elephants in the Greater Bangweulu wetland landscape. Kasanka elephants are no longer connected to other elephant populations. Poaching has decimated the wildlife in this park, reducing some species, like the puku antelope, by 90% in just five years. The objectives are to: 1) Develop a new law enforcement strategy focused on safeguarding elephants and in turn delivering conservation benefits to other species; 2) Establish a well-trained, well-equipped and well-motivated ranger team capable of tackling the poaching crisis; 3) Improve ranger accommodation and communication infrastructure to enable greater oversight and enhance coordination of anti-poaching operations; and, 4) Conduct efficient and effective intelligence-based anti-poaching activities to reduce poaching in and around the park.

title.narrative: Enhancing elephant protection in South Luangwa Valley, Zambia, through training new recruits, increasing the effectiveness of anti-poaching patrols and augmenting anti-poaching patrol support

description.narrative: This project is aimed at urgently addressing the critical shortage of wildlife police officers in and around South Luangwa National Park in eastern Zambia in order to combat an upsurge in elephant poaching. Specific activities will include coordinating and funding the screening, selection, and initial training of fifty new recruits; providing refresher training for existing officers and for local community scouts who patrol with them in adjacent Game Management Areas; and by providing much needed patrol equipment for anti-poaching and operational expenses for patrols by vehicle, boat, and on foot. Conservation South Luangwa is a non-governmental organization that has supported Zambias Department of Wildlife and National Parks for 15 years by providing technical and financial assistance to supplement the inadequate budget provided by the Zambian government for operation of the parks and adjacent wildlife areas.

title.narrative: Strengthening Law Enforcement Efforts in the Lower Zambezi, Zambia

description.narrative: The Lower Zambezi National Park (LZNP) in southern Zambia forms part of the greater Lower Zambezi Valley system, spanning across Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique, which was formerly a population stronghold for elephants. In 2016, 107 elephants were poached for their ivory in the LZNP and surrounding hunting blocks. In order to combat poaching, funds are requested to supporting the Dog Unit and the Special Response Unit, operational expenses for foot patrols by Department of National Parks and Wildlife and community scout teams, and aerial surveillance by Conservation Lower Zambezi, supporting a technical advisor and a legal assistant to the judiciary (in partnership with Zambias Wildlife Crime Prevention Project) and supporting meetings between Zambian and Zimbabwean park officials regarding transborder poaching and trafficking of the shared elephants of Lower Zambezi and Mana Pools.

title.narrative: Reducing the Illegal Wildlife Trade Across Southern Lake Tanganyika

description.narrative: Lake Tanganyika is located in northern Zambia and is the second largest freshwater lake in the world. It is home to an immense amount of biodiversity including hundreds of cichlid species. Many of the cichlid species are in high demand for the worldwide aquarium trade. In the first quarter of 2018, half of all illegal incidents in Nsumbu National Park (one of only three protected areas around Lake Tanganyika) were aquatic in nature. To address the illegal harvesting of protected cichlid species in Nsumbu National Park, this one-year grant will support: recruitment and training of rangers at Chunga Wildlife College, a requirement for rangers in Zambia; boat operation and aquatic training for existing rangers, including how to identify species and trade routes of cichlids to better direct law enforcement operations; workshops with relevant national wildlife and fisheries authorities on methods of live fish collection, international export routes, and value of fish exports; provision of fuel, rations, and boat engine maintenance to ensure continuity of aquatic patrols of Lake Tanganyika; and integration of the aquatic patrols into the wider law enforcement strategy for Nsumbu National Park to ensure intelligence and investigations are streamlined.

title.narrative: Engaging the communities living around North Luangwa National Park to foster support for black rhino conservation initiatives in Zambia

description.narrative: North Luangwa is home to Zambias largest and most stable elephant population and the countrys only black rhino population (reintroduced in 2003). In addition to traditional security, anti-poaching, and wildlife management, the North Luangwa Conservation Program in Zambia works to promote support among local people for conservation through outreach and education. To increase support for black rhino conservation and the protected areas, this grant supports the production of lesson plans and resource materials for 21 local schools, school visits by the programs outreach officer, training and mentoring for the officer and for appointed conservation teachers at each school, holding conservation celebration days; and conducting field trips with school or community groups into North Luangwa National Park.

title.narrative: Securing the greater North Luangwa landscape for the protection of black rhinos (Diceros bicornis minor) in North Luangwa National Park, Zambia

description.narrative: This proposal will provide ongoing support the rhino reintroduction of the southern black rhino (Diceros bicornis minor) subspecies to Zambia. In the past, Zambia had the highest number of rhinos of any African country, but they were poached to extinction in the 1990s. Throughout the early 2000s, USFWS sponsored efforts to restore security to North Luangwa National Park (NLNP) in eastern Zambia. The first rhinos were released in NLNP in 2003, and the population has increased steadily with no poaching in the past 15 years. Funds this year will support core operations including the construction of a new, modernized security operations room, road improvement within the secure area, and operating expenses for aerial and ground based monitoring and anti-poaching patrols.

title.narrative: COLLABORATIVE DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF GENETIC TOOLS, FORENSIC CAPACITY, AND LOCAL EXPERTISE TO COMBAT BIG CAT TRAFFICKING IN EASTERN AND SOUTHERN AFRICA

description.narrative: Big cats in Africa (lions, cheetahs and leopards) are declining across their range due to an array of human impacts, including poaching. The purpose of this project is to counter the trafficking of big cats in Eastern and Southern Africa (using Zambia as the model) through developing and applying a genetic tool to identify source populations of trafficked big cats and building in-country capacity for forensics and prosecutions of wildlife crimes. This project is intended to conserve lions, leopards, and cheetahs by reducing the impact of illegal offtake from poaching, driven in part by a growing market for body parts of big cats other than tigers. Specific activities of this two-year grant include: (1) ongoing development of a genetic tool to identify the source populations for trafficked lions and developing the same tools for leopards and cheetahs; (2) application of these methods to identify the source populations for 391 samples in hand from killed big cats in Zambia; (3) capacity development in Zambia by training relevant individuals in the use of genetic methods to combat wildlife trafficking; and (4) data collection on the geographic origin of big cat samples to the relevant officials to support targeted enforcement efforts.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING LAW ENFORCEMENT EFFORTS IN THE LOWER ZAMBEZI, ZAMBIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support an elephant conservation effort in Lower Zambezi National Park and surrounding Game Management Areas by strengthening elephant protection and biological monitoring, and improving protected area capacity development. As part of the Luangwa-Zambezi Valley savanna elephant stronghold, this ecosystem is home to Zambias largest population of elephants, with approximately 14,000 individuals. This project is intended to conserve African savanna elephants and their habitat by addressing the impacts of poaching, habitat loss, and loss of tourism revenue due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Specific activities include: (1) conducting ground and aerial law enforcement and monitoring patrols; (2) developing a long-term systematic training program for all law enforcement units in line with standard operating procedures and best practices, in addition to conducting refresher trainings for the Detection and Tracking Dog Unit; and (3) providing core operations support for a forward operating base, observation point, and control center.

title.narrative: SECURING THE GREATER NORTH LUANGWA LANDSCAPE FOR THE PROTECTION OF BLACK RHINOS (DICEROS BICORNIS MINOR) IN NORTH LUANGWA NATIONAL PARK, ZAMBIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in North Luangwa National Park, Zambia by proving necessary equipment and resources to monitor and protect its rhinoceros population. This project is intended to conserve the Southern Central black rhinoceros and their habitat by addressing the impacts of poaching for the illegal trade. Specific activities include: (1) purchasing field transport; and (2) providing aerial and ground based monitoring for security with the goal of maintaining a zero-poached status.

title.narrative: AFRICAN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to maintain anti-poaching pressure to conserve Zambias largest elephant population. Estimated at around 100,000 elephants in the 1970s, the Luangwa Valley still contains Zambias largest population of elephants, with around 14,000 individuals surviving across a complex of protected areas, game management areas, and village lands. Additionally, the Luangwa Valley is home to Zambias only population of black rhino. This project works with the Government of Zambia to support an anti-poaching presence in North Luangwa National Park, home to around 4,500 elephants, where sustained long-term efforts have reduced poaching in the park. Poaching incidents and other signs of illegal activities continue to increase in adjacent areas, however, and the elephant population is considered at risk of an escalation in illegal killing if support for anti-poaching efforts were to decrease. Specific activities include: (1) operational support for anti-poaching units, including patrols, rations, equipment, and deployment vehicles; and (2) park infrastructure development and maintenance, including road repairs and fire management.

title.narrative: ENHANCING PROTECTION OF ZAMBIA S SOUTH LUANGWA VALLEY AT-RISK ELEPHANT POPULATION, BY SUSTAINING CRITICAL ANTI-POACHING SUPPORT AND ADDRESSING INCREASING HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN SOUTH LUANGWA NATIONAL PARK BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION, BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. AS PART OF THE LUANGWA-ZAMBEZI VALLEY SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO ZAMBIA S LARGEST POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS, WITH APPROXIMATELY 14,000 INDIVIDUALS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT HEC , AND LOSS OF TOURISM REVENUE DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 PROVISIONING ADEQUATE FIELD SUPPLIES FOR YEAR-ROUND ANTI-POACHING PATROLS E.G., FOOD RATIONS, VEHICLE FUEL, AND VEHICLE SPARE PARTS AND PROCURING A SPEED BOAT AND ENGINE TO INCREASE RAINY SEASON PATROLS 2 PROVIDING OPERATIONAL SUPPORT TO THE CANINE DETECTION UNIT AND 3 EXPANDING HEC RAPID RESPONSE UNIT EFFORTS, INCLUDING PATROL DEPLOYMENT, CONSTRUCTION OF ELEPHANT-PROOF ELECTRIC FENCING AND GRAIN STORES TO REDUCE CROP RAIDING, AND CONDUCTING HEC SENSITIZATION AND AWARENESS PROGRAMMING.

title.narrative: ENHANCING PROTECTION OF ZAMBIA S SOUTH LUANGWA VALLEY AT-RISK ELEPHANT POPULATION, BY SUSTAINING CRITICAL ANTI-POACHING SUPPORT AND ADDRESSING INCREASING HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support an elephant conservation effort in South Luangwa National Park by strengthening elephant protection, biological monitoring, and community engagement. As part of the Luangwa-Zambezi Valley savanna elephant stronghold, this ecosystem is home to Zambias largest population of elephants, with approximately 14,000 individuals. This project is intended to conserve African savanna elephants and their habitat by addressing the impacts of poaching, human-elephant conflict (HEC), and loss of tourism revenue due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Specific activities include: (1) provisioning adequate field supplies for year-round anti-poaching patrols (e.g., food rations, vehicle fuel, and vehicle spare parts) and procuring a speed boat and engine to increase rainy season patrols; (2) providing operational support to the canine detection unit; and (3) expanding HEC Rapid Response Unit efforts, including patrol deployment, construction of elephant-proof electric fencing and grain stores to reduce crop raiding, and conducting HEC sensitization and awareness programming

title.narrative: SUPPORT FOR COMMUNITY-INCLUSIVE CONSERVATION OF AFRICAN ELEPHANT IN THE NORTH LUANGWA ECOSYSTEM, ZAMBIA

description.narrative: SUPPORT FOR COMMUNITY INCLUSIVE CONSERVATION OF AFRICAN ELEPHANT IN THE NORTH LUANGWA ECOSYSTEM, ZAMBIA THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN NORTH LUANGWA NATIONAL PARK (NLNP) BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND BUILDING A CONSTITUENCY FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION. AS PART OF THE LUANGWA ZAMBEZI VALLEY SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO ZAMBIA S LARGEST AND MOST STABLE POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS (APPROXIMATELY 14,000 INDIVIDUALS) AND ITS ONLY BLACK RHINO POPULATION. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HABITAT LOSS, HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC), AND LOSS OF TOURISM REVENUE DUE TO THE COVID 19 PANDEMIC. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) PROVIDING AERIAL ELEPHANT MONITORING SUPPORT FOR HEC AFFECTED COMMUNITIES IN NLNP ADJACENT GAME MANAGEMENT AREAS (2) PURCHASING RATIONS (MAIZE MEAL) FROM HEC AFFECTED COMMUNITIES TO ESTABLISH LINKS BETWEEN RURAL FARMING LIVELIHOODS AND ELEPHANT CONSERVATION AND (3) CONDUCTING HEC MITIGATION AND CONSERVATION EDUCATION AND OUTREACH WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING CONSTRUCTION OFELEPHANT PROOF GRAIN STORES, PURCHASE OF MOTORCYCLES TO ENABLE SAFE DELIVERY OF COMMUNITY LED MINI CHANGE PROJECTS, AND REGIONAL EXCHANG
